title: 111_hr3341
content: The Act may be cited as the "Ronald Reagan Commemorative Coin Act of 2009" and specifies the coin specifications. The "Ronald Reagan Commemorative Coin Act of 2009" authorizes the minting of $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. These coins are legal tender and considered numismatic items under the Act. According to title 31, United States Code, all coins minted under this Act are considered numismatic items. SEC. 3. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall feature former President Ronald Wilson Reagan on the obverse side and an American eagle carrying an olive branch on the reverse side. Each coin will also include inscriptions of the coin's value, the year "2013", and the words "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design for the coins will be selected according to the Act. The design for the coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 4. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single Mint facility. The Secretary can start issuing coins from January 1, 2013, and sales can begin before that date. Minting authority will end on December 31, 2013. SEC. 5. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and cost of designing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. The Secretary will add a surcharge to all coins minted under this Act, with $35 per coin for the $5 coin and $10 per coin for the $1 coin. Proceeds from these surcharges will be promptly paid to the Army Emergency Fund for financial assistance to Army active duty soldiers, National Guard members, and their dependents. The Army Emergency Fund provides financial assistance to Army active duty soldiers, National Guard members, and their dependents. Eligibility includes soldiers on active duty for over 30 days, retired soldiers, surviving spouses or dependent children of deceased soldiers. The fund is subject to audit requirements and there is a limitation on the number of commemorative coin programs issued annually. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance for programs exceeding the annual commemorative coin program issuance limitation under section 5112(m)(1) of title 31, United States Code.
